Award.AwardTitle: PECASE: Design Strategies to Benefit from the Profit-by-Poverty-Alleviation Paradox

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to create methods for designing extremely affordable products aimed at alleviating poverty in the developing world while simultaneously opening new foreign markets to US companies. Surprisingly, this approach of financially gaining from helping the poor to escape poverty is one of the most sustainable paths to poverty alleviation. Products designed using the methods created under this award foster self-sufficiency by increasing the earning power of those who are living in extreme poverty. These income-generating products are made affordable by their strategic modularity, which makes them progressively expandable, thus facilitating incremental investment by the impoverished. The research approach includes the creation of multidisciplinary decision-making models for extreme affordability, product expandability, and decision robustness. Deliverables include documented research results, and undergraduate and graduate teaching modules made available via the World Wide Web.

If successful, the research will result in the discovery and articulation of fundamental principles of sustainable design for the developing world. These principles, which enable affordable, low risk, products that increase the earning power of people living in extreme poverty, are the fundamental basis of the research and teaching modules resulting from this work. If successful, the research will positively affect many people's lives. For the impoverished, breakthroughs in affordability of income-generating products lead to increased income, which in turn lowers sickness, improves educational opportunities, improves local water supplies, and combats hunger. For US companies searching for new and suitable foreign markets, the proposed work provides needed design methods for creating viable products for those markets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to create a methodology for designing income-generating products aimed at alleviating poverty in the developing world. The methodology designs for extremely affordable products that foster self-sufficiency by increasing the earning power of those who are living in poverty. Under the developed approach, these income-generating products are made affordable by their strategic modularity, which makes them progressively expandable, thus facilitating incremental investment by the impoverished.

 

Outcomes related to Intellectual Merit: The research resulted in principles that govern successful engineering design in the developing world. In addition it resulted in multiobjective optimization techniques which seek designs that are desirable in both performance and affordability. Importantly, these optimization methods are valuable in and out of the context of poverty alleviation. The developed methods include Pareto Frontier Traversing, and Design Space Exploration with Dynamic Pareto Frontiers. 

 

Outcomes related to Broader Impact:  The methods developed as part of this project have the potential to affect many people's lives. For resource-poor individuals and families, breakthroughs in affordability of income-generating products lead to increases in income, which in turn lowers sickness, improves educational opportunities, improves local water supplies, and combats hunger. For those searching for new and suitable foreign markets, the outcomes provide needed design methodologies for creating viable products for those markets. Successfully accessing such markets results in engineering and manufacturing jobs in the US. The systematic look at poverty alleviation from an engineering perspective also has the potential to positively affect non-engineering efforts in poverty alleviation, such as social science. The principles and methods that were developed as part of this project are already resulting in products that are helping people escape poverty. For example a humanitarian organization worked closely with the principle investigator of this project to develop a human-powered well drilling machine to reach clean water at depths of 250 feet. The machines are now produced on two different continents and have helped at least 50,000 people have access to clean water in multiple countries. The machines have been valuable income-generating products for those who invest in them.
